etymologies: mid 16th century. Perhaps from Italian †mocaiardo haircloth, apparently earliest of camel or goat hair, with ending remodelled after -ado; or perhaps from mock + -ado; sense B. suggests that the word was early associated with mock. Florio glosses the Italian word as ‘the stuffe we call moccado’, although the identification may not be correct

definitions: A kind of fabric resembling velvet, much used for garments and trimmings in the 16th and 17th centuries.
